Copy.Pstm36:
Congratulations - your toddler is three!

Take some time out for yourself this month, browse through your old photos and enjoy reminiscing about the last three years.

Your toddler can now throw a ball and might even be able to scale a climbing frame and pedal a tricycle - a far cry from that tiny baby of three years ago!

Check out what developments to expect from your 3 year old over the next 6 months.
Copy.Pstm37:
This month, we've got a timely reminder of our advice on the art of sharing, with handy hints on how you can teach your child to share.

We've also got information to help if your child has suddenly become afraid of the dark. It's quite common but there are lots of ways to deal with it and help put their fear at bay.
Copy.Pstm38:
At this age, kids love to copy everything you do - although it's hard to believe someone would choose to have a go at ironing and vacuuming! It's a good idea to let them get involved when you can. Try giving your little one a duster, or letting them 'mop' the kitchen floor. And if they quickly lose interest, take heart from the fact that doing the housework is an excellent work-out for you!

Also this month, we've got advice on how to encourage your child's imagination. It's great for their brain development and great fun for you to take part in too.
Copy.Pstm39:
Are mealtimes sometimes a struggle in your household? If you're getting stressed at mealtimes because your toddler won't eat, don't worry - it's very common. Here are some tips to encourage them to eat up.

We've also got information on preschool safety at home and away. They will still need supervision but they can start to understand about dangers and what they can and can't play with.
Copy.Pstm40:
Got growing girls? Or are you bringing up boys?

This month, we look at the differences between boys and girls (apart from the obvious!), with our guide to bringing up boys and advice on raising girls. Most parents don't want to stereotype (cars and dinosaurs for boys, dolls and princesses for girls?) but are there traits that appear predominantly in boys, and others in girls? Or is it down to the way you parent?
Copy.Pstm41:
It doesn't seem possible that your little one is nearly ready for school - but the time is fast approaching, so it's a good idea to find out about your options. If you're not sure where to start, don't worry - we're on hand to help, with our guide to choosing the right school.

If you're worried about your child's development and you're not sure how they'll cope at school, read our advice. There's usually no need to panic - kids reach milestones at different stages and each one has their own unique talents.
Copy.Pstm42: Your little one is now three and a half and learning loads with everything they do. They will do things at their own pace and in their own time but there are some things you can do to encourage them too.
Copy.Pstm43: This month, we go back to look at discipline again. As your child gets older, you'll need to take a different approach - so it's probably a good idea to remind yourself of our hints and tips. Plus, a quick reminder of our advice on teaching little ones to share.
Copy.Pstm44:
When you hit the shops, if your child sees something they want, whether that's a bar of chocolate or a new bike, they're old enough to let you know all about it. If you hear a little voice saying 'I want that, Mummy' does your heart sink?

Find out why children do this and learn how to deal with it, setting boundaries and staying strong but being fair. It's our guide to dealing with pester power.

We've also got advice on fussy eaters. Your child might suddenly stop trying new foods or refuse anything other than nuggets and chips. This is completely normal and most children will go through a phase like this.
Copy.Pstm45:
If you're bringing up a child on your own, you may well feel that you never get a day off and you don't often have a chance to relax - from finding enough money and juggling work and childcare, to coping with emotional upheaval and the need to keep going for everyone's sakes. Here are top tips for coming out smiling and coping on your own day-to-day.

Plus, if you're struggling to stay afloat, get all the help and advice you need on our money pages.
Copy.Pstm46:
This month we look at getting the right work life balance plus some golden rules for a happy working mum.

It's time to start thinking about your child's birthday - your not-so-little one probably already knows what presents they'd like. But if you're planning on having some kind of party, don't forget to let friends and family know soon, so they can book the date.
Copy.Pstm47:
If your child is due to start school soon, read our guide to getting them settled in at school. The first day is always a challenge for your child and you, but it will soon be part of your daily routine.

Also this month, we've got advice on sibling rivalry. They might be competing for your attention or fighting over a new toy but don't worry too much, its perfectly normal and they'll probably have forgotten about it a hour or two later.
